prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCCCN 25-24, v7='0,1,2,3,4,5 v6=0,1,2,3, v5=01,2,3 v4=0,1, v3=0,1 + CN N=2-1+ CO J=2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=25-24 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. As bonus CN and CO will be also observed. CN will trace directly the photodissociation regions of the envelope (innermost and external layers). CO will provide the highest angular resolution view of the gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11") depending on the molecular transition. Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense PDR of CRL618. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed frequency bands.
The continuous frequency coverage between 226.1 and 231 GHz is necessary to cover all lines of HCCCN vibrationally excited. Hence, the required data rate is justified scientifically. CN will trace the photodissociation region of HCN while CO will trace the high velocity outflow and the inner structure of the central torus.
The requested spectral resolution will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL618 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the photodissociation region 5-10 km/s).
The total observing time is 51 min of which 17 corresponds to on-source integration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CCH N=3-2 HCCCN J=29-28 HCN J=3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position woth frequency setup covering the J=29-28 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. CCH N=3-2 and HCN J=3-2 will be also observed. CCH N=3-2 will trace directly the photodissociation region of acetylene in the envelope (innermost and external layers). HCN will provide the highest angular resolution view of the dense gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the central torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11") depending on the molecular transition. Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense PDR of CRL618. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed frequency bands.
The continuous frequency coverage between 262.5 and 266.4 GHz is necessary to cover all lines of HCCCN vibrationally excited. Hence, the required data rate is justified scientifically.
The requested spectral resolution will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL618 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the photodissociation region 5-10 km/s).
The total observing time is 60 min of which 23 corresponds to on-source integration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HNC & HCO+ 3-2 + H29a + HC3N 28-27
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=3-2 lines of HNC and HCO+ J=3-2. In the lower band H29a and the J=28-27 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1 will be also observed. HCO+ will trace the ion-neutral chemistry while HNC will be a primary tracer of photochemistry and ion-neutral reactions. HCCCN will trace mainly the photochemistry of the dense gas. H29a will trace the inner and dense HII region (size 0.5") placed in the middle of the central torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11") depending on the molecular transition. Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense PDR of CRL618 (HCO+, HNC, HCCCN and the recombination lines of atomic hydrogen). The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed frequency bands.
The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed band coverage. They will correspond to typically 3".
The four proposed bands for this science goal are necessary to trace the molecular ionized gas (HCO+), the photochemical region producing HNC, the atomic ionized gas (H29a) and the photochemistry of HC3N (J=28-27) for which many lines from vibrationally excited states will be detected. Hence, the required data rate is justified scientifically.
The requested spectral resolution will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL618 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the photodissociation region 5-10 km/s).
The total observing time is 54 min of which 19 corresponds to on-source integration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL2688:: HCCCN 25-24, v7='0,1,2,3,4,5 v6=0,1,2,3, v5=01,2,3 v4=0,1, v3=0,1 + CN N=2-1+ CO J=2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=25-24 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. As bonus CN and CO will be also observed. CN will trace directly the photodissociation regions of the envelope (innermost and external layers). CO will provide the highest angular resolution view of the gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11"). Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense internal region of CRL2688 depending on the molecular transition. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed band coverage.
The continuous frequency coverage between 226.1 and 231 GHz is necessary to cover all lines of HCCCN vibrationally excited. Hence, the required data rate is justified scientifically. CN will trace the photodissociation region of HCN while CO will trace the high velocity outflow and the inner structure of the central torus.
The requested spectral resolution will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL2688.
The total observing time is 51 min of which 17 corresponds to on-source integration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL2688:: CCH N=3-2 HCCCN J=29-28 HCN J=3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position woth frequency setup covering the J=29-28 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. CCH N=3-2 and HCN J=3-2 will be also observed. CCH N=3-2 will trace directly the photodissociation region of acetylene in the envelope (innermost and external layers). HCN will provide the highest angular resolution view of the dense gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the central torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11"). Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense internal region of CRL2688 depending on the molecular transition. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed band coverage.
The continuous frequency coverage between 262.5 and 266.5 GHz is necessary to cover all lines of HCCCN vibrationally excited. Hence, the required data rate is justified scientifically.
The requested spectral resolution will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL2688.
The total observing time is 60 min of which 24 corresponds to on-source integration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe two carbon-rich protoplanetary nebulae (PPNe), CRL 618 and CRL 2688, to investigate the physical and chemical conditions that lead to complex hydrocarbon chemistry in the circumstellar environment of evolved stars after the AGB phase. Polyacetylenes and cyanopolyynes have been detected with ISO in both sources. However benzene, the first aromatic ring, is only seen in CRL 618. Only CRL 2688 shows emission from dust grains rich in aliphatics. For both molecules and grains, UV-processing was invoked as a key process in driving the chemical evolution.
We want to explore the emission of vibrationally excited HCCCN in both sources, CCH, HCN, CN and CO to constraint the physical and chemical conditions. In addition towards CRL 618, HCO+ and a recombination line of Hydrogen will be observed to better characterize the photodissociation region (PDR) at the interface between the HII region and the torus. Only ALMA can addressed this project since PPNe have complex morphologies and the most active chemistry is expected to occur in the densest part at scales of 0.2 to ~1". We will obtain unique data to investigate carbonaceous grain formation and evolution.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Planétologie

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Institut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Planétologie
